Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.description: A bacterial infection caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria, leading to small, dark, water-soaked spots on pepper leaves and fruits.
Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.remedy: Use certified disease-free seeds, avoid overhead irrigation, rotate crops, and spray copper-based bactericides.

Pepper__bell___healthy.description: Healthy pepper leaves show uniform green color without lesions, spots, or wilting.
Pepper__bell___healthy.remedy: Maintain balanced fertilizer use, proper watering, and periodic pest monitoring to keep the plant disease-free.

Potato___Early_blight.description: A common fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani, producing dark concentric rings on older leaves.
Potato___Early_blight.remedy: Remove affected leaves, avoid wet foliage, and apply Mancozeb 75 WP or Chlorothalonil fungicide at early stages.

Potato___Late_blight.description: A serious fungal disease caused by Phytophthora infestans, leading to black lesions on leaves and stems, with white mold under humid conditions.
Potato___Late_blight.remedy: Avoid waterlogging, use certified seeds, destroy infected plants, and apply Metalaxyl or Copper oxychloride fungicide.

Potato___healthy.description: The potato plant shows no visible signs of blight, yellowing, or leaf spotting.
Potato___healthy.remedy: Ensure proper spacing, balanced irrigation, and use crop rotation to maintain soil health and prevent disease buildup.

Tomato_Bacterial_spot.description: Caused by Xanthomonas bacteria, resulting in small dark spots with yellow halos on leaves and fruits, leading to defoliation.
Tomato_Bacterial_spot.remedy: Use clean seeds, avoid working in wet fields, and apply copper-based bactericides regularly.

Tomato_Early_blight.description: A fungal infection caused by Alternaria solani; it produces concentric brown spots on lower, older leaves first.
Tomato_Early_blight.remedy: Remove infected leaves, avoid overhead watering, rotate crops, and apply Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil fungicide.

Tomato_Late_blight.description: Caused by Phytophthora infestans, it creates large water-soaked lesions that quickly turn brown or black on leaves and stems.
Tomato_Late_blight.remedy: Avoid wet leaves, destroy infected plants, and spray Ridomil Gold or Metalaxyl-based fungicides.

Tomato_Leaf_Mold.description: A fungal disease caused by Passalora fulva, visible as yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces and grayish mold on undersides.
Tomato_Leaf_Mold.remedy: Improve ventilation, reduce humidity, and use fungicides like Chlorothalonil or copper sprays.

Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Caused by Septoria lycopersici fungus, forming small circular spots with dark borders on lower leaves that later yellow and fall.
Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.remedy: Prune infected leaves, avoid splashing water, and apply fungicides containing copper or chlorothalonil.

Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.description: Caused by Tetranychus urticae mites that suck sap, leaving yellow stippling and webbing on undersides of leaves.
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.remedy: Spray neem oil or insecticidal soap, maintain leaf moisture, and introduce natural predators like ladybugs.

Tomato__Target_Spot.description: Fungal disease caused by Corynespora cassiicola, forming brown concentric target-like spots on leaves and fruits.
Tomato__Target_Spot.remedy: Remove infected leaves, increase air circulation, and use preventive fungicides like Mancozeb or Azoxystrobin.

Tomato__Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.description: Transmitted by whiteflies; symptoms include yellowing, upward curling of leaves, and stunted plant growth.
Tomato__Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.remedy: Control whiteflies with insecticides, remove infected plants, and use resistant tomato varieties.

Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: A viral disease causing mosaic-like mottling, leaf distortion, and stunted growth, spreading through contact and tools.
Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.remedy: Disinfect tools, avoid smoking near crops, and use virus-free seeds or resistant varieties.

Tomato_healthy.description: Healthy tomato leaves are green, smooth, and free of lesions or curling. Indicates good plant management and no infection.
Tomato_healthy.remedy: Maintain proper irrigation, balanced NPK fertilizer, and inspect regularly to prevent disease onset.
